ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to use MATLAB to analyze clinically-relevant data and how to build computational models to explain happiness, reinforcement learning, prospect theory, and more.

Knowledge and insights in decision-making, reinforcement-learning, happiness within the computational modeling perspectives. Model-free and model-based analysis skills. Related experiment design and online data collection skills.
I received an intensive overview of how to model and design research in computational neuroscience.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed the small classroom setting and discussions we had. I wish we had learned a bit more of the background on prospect theory, reinforcement learning, and such during class, which would have helped with the psets because we would have known what to expect from the data or what a "correct answer" would most likely look like. Essentially, more background during class. I appreciated the clear and timely feedback on each assignment!

The strength is very hands-on problem sets and very direct application to research.

The weakness is the coverage of the broader topics.

The small course size was a definite plus. I do think if I had even a small amount less coding knowledge the course would have been inaccessible or too high a time commitment. Perhaps 1 or two fewer problem sets would make the course more manageable:

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly highly recommend this course to any student interested in learning how to analyze behavioral data or what goes into a computational mode. It is unlike any other class I have taken at college, and I loved it!
I would strongly recommend this class to others graduate fellow students as it serves the research purpose I a very straight-forward manner.

I would recommend this to any graduate student doing applied microeconomic work. One gets exposure to a new way to do behavioral microeconomic research and also gets time to think through research of ones own interest. It also allows for a great way to refine coding skills.
